data.title: Exceeded expectations -thanks Jared!
data.text:
My boyfriend and I recently spent a long weekend in Boston and after a few days of exploring some of the best old pubs in town we wanted to kick it up a notch and enjoy a fancy night out. The Oceanaire delivered in every way; from the soaring ceilings, old bank vault, marble and Art Deco-like decor it had the feel of an old supper club but with a modern twist.  

We've had the pleasure of dining in many truly great restaurants and I will add this to our list. Not the least of which was down to the superior service.  Our server, Jared, made our night a truly excellent experience; more than dinner, it became a highlight of our trip thanks to the fun event he turned our dinner into! He was extremely knowledgable from the seafood to the wine and he struck the perfect personable balance with us.  Every recommendation he made was fantastic and we really appreciated his surprise of Boston Cream Pie for my first trip to Boston!  Ask to be seated in Jared's section and you're in for a remarkable evening. A true professional with a great sense of humour.  Thanks, from your Canadian couple Monday night!

data.title: Terrific food, expensive
data.text: We have eaten at the Oceanaire in Indianapolis for years. Food and service have always been excellent.  Same in Boston.

data.title: Looking for great dinner!
data.text: Wonderful meal! Oyster selection was great...knowledgeable waiter...ambiance great! Enjoyed thoughly! Didn't think plan on going to OCEANAIRE ...looking for local...couldn't get reservations elsewhere, but was THE BEST experience! Recommend highly!

data.title: They obviously didn't get why we asked about Happy Hour
data.text:
We went to the restaurant with a reservation, but asked them if happy hour was on.  They seated us at a table, gave us the regular menu, and told us that happy hour was only at the bar -- well why did you seat us at a table if that was the case.

We ordered anyhow -- Drinks, lobster Tails, and Brussel Sprouts -- it was a nice appetizer, and a refreshing drink.  But it was $100 -- and we were expecting less, and wanted more -- like oysters more.

Oh -- and the twin lobster tails were grilled way too much, and were way too tiny...

Next time, we will be clearer with the hostess.

data.title: A first class dining experience
data.text: Six of us in Boston for business dined at 8:00PM.  All of us enjoyed our dinners with the mixed seafood grill being most popular.  We also shared a selection of oysters which were really excellent.  Despite dining relatively late we were not at all rushed and the service was excellent.

data.title: Keep your expectations very low
data.text:
I chose this restaurant as it was very close to where I stayed and thought that I couldn't go wrong with my choice.
It is a member of a large chain restaurant and the food choices are very wide. However, the freshness and taste are less than mediocre. I had crab as my main course but I was very disappointed with the freshness of the food. Also decoration is very old-fashioned and boring.
Only good thing was the friendly service that I got.
You can definetely avoid this restaurant.

data.title: Elegant.  Excellent.  Really,
data.text: Loved this place for an elegant evening.  The ambiance is beautiful and elegant, the waiters attentive yet unobtrusive.  Well trained to provide you with a classy experience.  The food was delicious, elegantly presented and they don't skimp on the portions.  The side dishes were terrific.  Had the Ritzy halibut.  Highly recommend this.

data.title: Great Customer Service & Food
data.text: My daughter and I asked for a close by seafood restaurant after looking for the site of the Boston Massacre. We wanted lobster for our last night. Around the corner we found this wonderful and beautiful restaurant. My phone was about to die. They let me charge it at the front desk. They seated us even though we clearly were under-dressed compared to the clientele. They had a lobster special that was reasonable. We sat down and waited, but really not obsessively. I was not looking around and at my watch. The next thing I know the manager, Gil Jimenez, brought over one of his best waiters, Hans Hoffens, and apologized for the wait and offered us a free appetizer, even though I had not complained and was clear that it was ok. The meal was more than incredible, and they were very attentive, including Stafia and I think it might have been Bailey. At the end, Hans surprised us with a Bakes Alaska desert, no charge. I had not had Baked Alaska and my daughter, in town for a college visit and only 17, never had either. We were overwhelmed with the service provided by Gil and Hans and the others. Great job Oceanaire!

data.title: Someone MUST get the scallops with Ritz crackers!
data.text: Great fresh seafood restaurant in a beautiful old building with tall ceilings and great service. Jerad was our waiter and he suggests the scallops as a "traditional" Boston meal. It was amazing!  I highly recommend it even if you don't eat scallops. The fish tacos were not as good though but the sho strings fries are a great side!

data.title: A special evening
data.text: Ate at this restaurant with a group of 12 people.  Walking in made me gasp.  It is gorgeous.  They sat us in a semi-private room still connected to the main restaurant but quieter.  The food was delious and the server treated us like royalty being helpful with advice when we needed it.  He even dived up the bill on 12 different credit cards.  I would definitely return when I return to Boston.

data.title: Not bad if a bit slow.
data.text:
Was visiting from Ireland in October and this place came highly recommended from one of our Uber drivers.

The restaurant itself is quite impressive, high ceiling and large. Everything about it is pretty slick and professional, but it does slightly lack any sort of personal touch. The food was very good and thoroughly enjoyable, but I did feel the service was a little on the slow side, which surprised me as we visited mid-week and yes there were a few people around, but the place isn't what you would call busy.

I would still recommend the place if you're a seafood lover and whatever you order make sure you order the hash brown with it.

Long story short, it's very good, it's pricey enough and it all sort of feels a bit corporate.

data.title: Make digestion between plates in a noisy place
data.text:
The Oceanaire it's a fine place to go for group dinners and for that reason tend to be very noisy. The service despite the restaurant not be very crowded, took ages, even if the request was mainly raw food, and soups. The food quality it's good, but you don't enjoy it, due the gaps between plates. 
Not a place to repeat.

data.title: Everything was perfect
data.text: Everydish I tried was perfection. tried the lobster bisque which was rich and creamy, crabcakes were delicious and beautifully done.  Had the prawn dish with angel hair pasta. there was no room left for dessert. Servers were attentive,

data.title: Best yet
data.text: Business meeting with 16 people. The staff were excellent and the food was better. Try the poke, you will not be disappointed. Great assortments of wine. Best restaurant yet.

data.title: Great place for a special dinner
data.text:
Four of us were here on a Sunday evening for my daughter's birthday celebration. Beginning with the menus printed with Happy Birthday along the top, we knew it would be a special evening.

First, the highlights: fabulous cocktail list, briny fresh oysters on the half shell, extensive wine list, including many by the glass selections, fresh seafood and delicious steaks, and side dishes for sharing that were delicious. 

We started with warm sourdough bread and butter and our cocktails (I recommend the perfect G&T) and moved to a shared plate of a variety of the freshest oysters.  My husband had a bowl of Sherried Lobster Bisque (with several large chunks of lobster meat) and I started with the Burrata Salad (one of the creamiest balls of burrata I've ever experienced.) My daughter had Spicy Tuna Poke, a combination of chopped raw tuna in a spicy sauce served on three layers of crisp, flat wonton.  I got to taste both that and the soup and I would have loved any of them. 

Main courses were filets for everyone but me (why go to a seafood restaurant and order beef, I ask?) Everyone seemed to enjoy their steaks, my husband added some shrimp to his, and the meat was cooked to the proper medium and medium rare as ordered.  Sides were incredible: really amazing Lobster mac 'n cheese (easily a meal by itself; it was so rich I could only eat a couple of bites), Shaved Brussels Sprouts with bacon dressing and crisp parmesan crumbs, grilled asparagus, and sautéed spinach.  My main course was Sesame Seared Yellowfin Ahi Tuna. I requested it VERY rare (I really don't like cooked tuna) and it came out perfect: basically raw tuna with the very slightest crisp edges, thin-sliced and served Sashimi style.  The sesame seeds gave it a slight crunch that was a lovely counterpoint to the creamy tuna.

I probably had the best Key Lime Pie I've ever eaten for dessert, and they served such a large slice I couldn't finish it all.  Creme Brûlée was enjoyed by my husband.  The restaurant brought the birthday girl a huge Baked Alaska (on the house), flamed it at the table, and served us all a goodly portion of it.  Gratefully, no silly singing accompanied dessert. She and I had a lovely 50-year old port to go with our dessert.

Having said all that, and it really was a great evening, I still have a few comments that are less than positive:

We were seated right next to the waiters' station, even though the restaurant was virtually empty when we arrived.  I should have requested another table and didn't.  Having the waitstaff moving around right behind me, seeing platters of food sitting there, having them entering orders on the computer... all very distracting from the dining experience.

The presentation of the oysters and appetizers was a bit disjointed.  They all came out at once (even though we thought we had made it clear we wanted the oysters first and then the apps) and our table was so crowded the waiter ended up pulling up all the leaves on the table to make it larger. Awkward, at best, since the food was already there and we were seated.

One of our party is both gluten and dairy sensitive, which was made known at the time of the reservation.  There was very little she could eat and we weren't offered alternatives to anything.  We were able to get the spinach and asparagus without dairy or breadcrumbs and she had the filet, but there were no starch options that were gluten/dairy free, nor were there any desserts she could eat. 

We had ordered a Port from the drinks menu and it wasn't available.  Someone from the bar came over and offered us an alternative, which we accepted.  While it wasn't a real problem, it was 25% more expensive than what we originally ordered and we weren't warned about the cost.  My feeling was if they were going to substitute a higher priced wine for one they didn't have they should either tell me the uncharge or charge the same as the original that we picked.  

Aside from those few glitches, it was a fantastic meal for a special occasion.  It's quite an expensive restaurant so I, at least, won't be stopping in regularly, but if you can handle the bill, go for it!

data.title: Fine dining with splendid seafood
data.text: Oceanaire was just a short walk from our hotel. The front of house staff had been very helpful the day before when we were looking for somewhere to eat, and recommended the place we eventually went to. We had liked the look of Oceanaire so made a reservation for a special occasion meal to mark our final night in Boston before returning home. Oceanaire is high end seafood dining. The choice is almost overwhelming. We were guided through the menu by a very helpful server. When it arrived, it was the best seafood we had eaten for years. A restaurant of this quality is not cheap, but it's worth the cost.

data.title: Horrible service....but
data.text: My friend and I came here last night and from the minute we walked in, the service was horrible.  We made a reservation 3 days ago and requested a booth and that request was not honored. No big deal, we were seated elsewhere.  After 10 minutes of no service, not even a glass a water, we asked a manager if there was a waiter assigned to our table and he looked confused and then sent over one of the bartenders to take our order.  After another 15 minutes, the waitress/bartender informed us that they ran out of 2lb lobsters which we had both ordered.  Their solution was to replace the 2lb lobster with two 1 1/4lb lobsters but wanted to charge us for the extra 1/2lb.  They should have just charged us for the price of the 2lb lobster since it wasn't our fault they ran out.   They finally brought us our lobsters but they they forgot to bring our side order of hash browns.  I also realized at this point that we never received our bread or complimentary olives/radishes/pickles.  When I brought this up to the manager "Gil", he said he cleared them from our table when he served us our appetizers essentially calling me a liar.  He insisted he did and ran around away and never saw him again.  Then another manager "Luca" came over and asked how our dinner was.  We proceeded to explain to him the comedy of errors and at least he was professional enough to apologize and make good for all of the service issues by adjusting our bill accordingly.  Overall, the food was good as usual but probably the most disappointing aspect of the evening was the first manager Gil's unprofessional attitude and inability to rectify the service issues.

data.title: Nothing Spectacular
data.text: Even though we have our favorites in Boston, we always like to try somewhere new. This restaurant was simply ok, nothing over the top and nothing too bad. One thing that really angered me and put a bad taste in our mouths before we'd even tasted the food was how we were greeted. We had reservations and arrived about 20 minutes early--when using public transit in Boston, you always leave early just in case--and were made to wait. The hostess suggested we go have a few drinks and wait for our table; we are not drinkers and there were no seats at the bar anyway. We would've waited outside but it was pouring so we waited in the vestibule. The valet guy finally tired of us being in his way and all of a sudden a table was ready. Mind you, there were many open tables in the dining room when we arrived. Now, on to the meal. Our server was all right, we had crab cakes and swordfish which were prepared well and tasted good. Lastly, the dessert we had was not "traditional" Boston Cream Pie as the filling was a little off, but it was huge and stilly tasty all the same (see photo). In a place like Boston there are a ton of awesome seafood restaurants, not sure we'd head back to this one.

data.title: Go have a look
data.text: By all means step inside and see what the restaurant has done with one of the oldest banks in Boston. Amazing. But even a glass of water is $$$$$

data.title: Scrumptious food and Decor!
data.text: The moment my wife and I entered the restaurant I knew we were in for a real treat. Lovely booths and tables and bar were available for our choice. Though on the pricey side, this restaurant is worth it.  Seafood was scrumptious, and wine list had some very nice California and French wines.
